reviews.text: The best part about this museum is how it shows the progression of Picasso's art, from his early more traditional work to the progression to his infamous style.

I bought a ticket and went to the museum as an art lover but not into Picasso and I left a Picasso fan!  First of all, finding the entrance is a little weird but cool at the same time.  I did the audio tour and love it.  When I finished I went back to our hotel and we spent the evening looking up and learning more about Picasso and his life and work.

Location was a little confusing even with my Google map. I kept missing the entrance as the sign-board was small and hard to see. It was not very crowded when i got there in the late afternoon so priority queue ticket was not necessary. The museum was housed in a beautiful medieval palace dating back to the 13th-14th century. The building itself worth exploration on it own. Besides the building, this is a must visit for Picasso fan, art enthusiast or just curioso like me who wanted to know more about once of the most influencing artist in 20th century. The collections is massive, showcasing Picasso life, and changes in his artistic view over the year chronically. The museum also allowed photo taking with a flash so it was good for memory. I especially enjoy the display of his works during his teens (14 years old! - such talent!); his blue paintings and the last part - conceptualization of his Las Meninas from the same by Diego Velázquez. Highly recommend.

This museum is fantastic. It outlines Picasso’s life and strangely allows you to photograph the artwork! But that’s the allure of Picasso, the strange and alluring!

It takes a bit to find the museum but the location is fantastic. Everyone knows what a Picasso painting looks like but what is far more interesting is his early work from when he was 15. 

His early work is in a classic portrait style where Picasso is learning his craft. Even at an early age he was extremely talented. Interestingly there is no indication at all of the artistic genius that Picasso was to become. 

It does take a bit to get your head around the sudden, left field turn in his art. 

A word of caution. The museum doesn’t contain his most famous piece ‘Guernica’. That is in Madrid. However that doesn’t take away the excellence of this museum. 

We didn’t take the audio guide. We just enjoyed the craziness of the art.
Found this completely on accident wandering the streets- I had no idea how diverse his works were- an truly exceptional discovery. A must do for fine art fans.
Hard to get to if you dont know where you're going.  Reasonably priced, clean and friendly staff.  Obvs the artwork is amazing!
This museum provides an opportunity to see the art that Picasso produced as a child - why he was recognized as a prodigy

I appreciate art! But this museum was amazing! I had no idea about the variety of ways Picasso expressed himself!! This was a was wonderful exhibition. Totally worth the extra money for the audio tour that went along with the exhibition! You need at least 2.5 - 3hrs. Also recommended buying tickets online before going. No line to wait in!!

Not too long a wait to get in and used a locker for are bags. Not really very busy in the morning when we arrived. 
So pleased to see the art work all set out well . Took a good hour we didn’t do the full tour.
It's a beautiful musuem. It's very nice to go through his live by his art. You can go for free on sundays after 3pm, you have to book it online.

Beautiful museum. The part I liked the most was Picasso’s work on the Meninas (Velazquez). Visited with two kids (8-11) who liked and enjoyed the visit. Is a small museum so it is very enjoyable. Get there early to avoid the crowds

The museum walk through recounts the life and career of the famous painter, showing the evolution of the work that made him famous. A cornerstone of a visit to barcelona, certainly worth the time and money. I saw a review saying confusing....it was pretty simple really...just walk forward and watcxh his life progress. The gift shop is very overpriced, but otherwise, this is a great place to visit.

Really interesting to see such a variety of his work including some amazing pieces completed in his early teens.  So talented. The museum venue itself is really impressive in its own right too. Point knocked off for being pretty confusing on entry with pre-booked tickets audio guide not only not included but not even clear where to get one.

Small museum focusing on early life of the artist. Availability of English language guided tours is low, so if you are interested make sure to make reservations. We did not do it and strolled with the audio guide ( it is not free you have to add extra euro or two). The building itself is beautiful, it is 4 palaces joined together and they are in complete opposite to the modern style of the paintings. The staff in the rooms is knowledgeable and courteous. To sum up- if you like Picasso you would probably enjoy this museum. If you do not have enough time for your visit in Barcelona you may as well skip it.

We’ve been to the Picasso Museum in Paris before and we enjoyed this one just as much if not more. You should buy tickets in advance which means you need to pick the day and time of your visit. It made for a comfortable visit with not too many people. The building housing the art work is old with lots of character and adds to the art displays.

I'm not a fan of Picasso. I appreciate my sister was interested. As it is free today because it's a holiday here and a cold day, I went but usually they charge.

If you go, you have to put your water bottle in the locker provided so you'd need 1euro.

Would not go back as not a fan.

Prefer the Sagrada Familia!

What luck!  We came into Barcelona on a national holiday when all the museums and churches were offering free admission.  We couldn't just walk in but had to obtain timed tickets for later in the day, but what a treat and worth the wait.  By the end of the day, we didn't have to put up with crowds and could drink in the art works at our own pace. A great way to start our stay in Barcelona.

In a city full of pricey tourist traps, the Picasso Museum is almost a hidden gem. The collection is extensive and encompasses the whole life of the artist, including of course his well-known later style. All in a beautiful building. Definitely the highlight of my trip to Barcelona.
It was cool to see some of the less famous pieces. I especially liked the exhibit with his interpretation of Velazquez's Meninas. Also, the building itself is super gorgeous.

Interesting exhibit with much of his early work. It’s especially interesting to see his pre-abstract stuff. Also has all of his Les Meninas stuff. Beautiful building. Get the Barcelona pass and you can skip the line!
Great museum. There was a great temporary exhibition on which was really good. Staff are very helpful. There is a free entry on Thursday evenings but you have to prebook

If you are an artistic person i would recommend you to see that excibition!
We bought tickets from the museum for 12€ per person and we were waiting only for 10 minutes.
The audio guide was very helpful !
This museum was wonderful! Definitely buy your tickets ahead of time to insure you get in. The audio guide was well worth the money. Very good experience!!!

This is a nice museum. It has a lot of bredth to it that you don't see in museums that only have a few of the more major works by Picasso. His earlier works are really cool to see, and might convert you if you aren't into cubism. It only takes an hour or two, too, which is great if you are on a tight schedule or just looking for something leisurely to do on a Saturday. Make sure to look up Velazquez's Las Meninas and some of the commentary about it ahead of time if you aren't already familiar. It will make the last room way more fun for you.

Museum is located on edge of Gothic area in Barcelona, in a lovely renovated older building.  It contains everal very early paintings from when he attended art school in teens in Barcelona.  We took a Picasso walking tour thru the Gothic area, with the guide discussing the influence that Barcelona had on Picasso's early pictures.  Very informative.  Then he took us as a group into the museum, explaining signifcance of verious painting.  I encourage you to take walking tour with ending in the museum.  Wonderful way to experience the museum.

We were able to go in without tickets thanks to the Articket. The museum was not overly-crowded and we enjoyed the collections - especially from the blue period. The organization of the museum was well done, and found much of the work inspiring.
Overhyped and insufficient. Confusing and tiring. Very little services offered to the visitor. Still i dont regret the visit
Great visit! Purchasing the tickets online is a must with an arrival time. We enjoyed seeing the artists works as we walked through the exhibits. A must see while in Barcelona.

We went with my husband and kids to this Museum. After spending few days inside museums and Churches in Barcelona, the kids were already complaining about the visit to this museum. They have a kids audio guide for them to help them to browse around. We have been in many museums and this is a great one with a lot of information and in a beautiful building. I had to go throw the museum fast with them as their guide was shorter than mine. I felt that they could have more for the kids as Picasso is usually an artist that kids know. Something that they can draw or trace to keep them entertained and parents can enjoy their visit too. In any case itsa great museum and a most seen in Barcelona

It is amazing to see an entire museum devoted to Picasso’s works. It had his early works which were very traditional and showed that he was so talented. It proceeds to the modern style that we are accustomed to seeing. It is worth your time if you enjoy art.

We visited the museum recently on December 24 this year. The museum was open. However, all the washrooms were closed to the visitors!!! 
The employees were on strike. They were outside the museum handing out info sheets about the strike and asking for donation money. After purchasing the tickets, we were informed that the washroom were closed to the visitors due to the strike. 
The employee working at the ticket stand told me that we could use the washrooms at another museum across the street but there was no other washroom to use!!
The building across the street that looked like a museum was closed. 
Guess what? My two children and I had to rush down all of the street looking for a washroom. All the shops on the street did not let us use the washrooms. The only coffee shop open denied the use of washroom, saying it was wet and under cleaning. 
I literally almost peed myself. 
After half an hour running around all the nearby streets and begging the shop owners for washroom use, a gift shop owner let us to use his washroom. It was the most horrible experience in my life !!! 
If the museum was charging entrance to the visitors, regardless of the strike, the washrooms have to be allowed to the visitors. 
If the employees are taking their jobs seriously, they should be have all stopped working and closed down the museum. Instead, they choose to make the visitors suffer with no access to the washrooms.The way the employees are pursuing their objectives was inhuman. 
Picasso's art is beautiful but art come after your basic human needs. 
Think twice before purchasing the tickets unless you can hold your pee for several hours.

I was not a Picasso fan before visiting, but the museum iwell worth the time. You will learn a great deal about the artist’s life and the border of where his politics met his art. The only downside is the museum is a bit hard to navigate, so make sure to not miss any of the rooms. Book tickets the day before as they were sold out when we got there in the morning. The audio guide is helpful, but it is inconsistent in all the rooms.

I was impressed by how many pieces were in the collection. Plan for 2 hours to see both permanent and temporary collections. I especially enjoyed seeing Picasso's early work before his break with reality. I didn't realize he did such beautiful work.

I can’t express enough how fantastic this museum is.     I have never seen so much of PIcasso’s art in one place.     Check out his interpretation of Las Meninas.    Simply genius.    I appreciated the dedication to identifying the times in his life—-the displays were mostly chronological.    And his friendships, Man Ray, to name one, are also beautifully represented.    This is probably my favorite museum.

Placed in attractive location, near Las Ramblas street and in fantastic medieval ambient, Picasso's museum was overall great experience in Barcelona. Museum is full of his earlier works which are not so familiar to the public. You can see his development from some realistic paintings and works to much appreciated works of cubism. Those works including paintings, sculpture, pottery and fabrics. We went on free thursday so that was also a plus for a museum!

This museum is a walking tour of Picasso's life and allo was you to explore the wide range of work: paintings, sculpture; pottery; jewelry and fabrics.  I did not realize that Impressionism was not the only medium in which he excelled.  The tour has handicapped vaccess and it is easy to  see everything, you just need about three hours!  Not to be missed

For true Picasso fans. It has a great collection, but to me, a regular person looking into art, felt a little too much of the same over and over. I could of have done without it, since some of his fantastic work is spread all over the world in different museums, and we have had a chance to see it before. But for art buffs, I am sure it is a masterpiece.

I really enjoyed this museum. Much larger than expected and many more works of art than I would have imagined. 

They do a great job telling the artist’s history and journey. It was interesting and so impressive. Highly recommend.
We was expecting to see Picasso works, but it looks more a exposition of sketches. It was disappointing. I don't recommend this museum at Barcelona.

I was excited to see the works of Picasso in this museum. Sadly there are only one or two items that are of first tier quality. There is a lot of history and minor works and sketches from the artist. I do not think I would recommend this museum to others visiting Barcelona.

Go in the AM before it gets busy.  In November, wear your jacket because you move in and out of buildings and it can get chilly.  The breadth of styles of Picasso wasn't so apparent to me until this self guided audio tour - fascinating!

One of the nicer Picasso museums, several of which can be found in his native Spain.  This one has representative examples of his artwork from when he was a teenager until he was a senior citizen.  Located in the Old Town part of Barcelona, walking distance to the Barcelona Cathedral, their waterfront, and multiple Metro lines.

Unbelievably great museum covering the early genius of Picasso: The ROOT of it all that you need to plant your mind on.
Q-Trip: Barcelona Tourism (our guide Xavier) provided 
             an excellent background on Picasso, his life 
             in Barcelona, and some of his 7 different studios. 
             Great discourse THEN the guide takes you through 
             the museum highlighting the most important aspects 
             of a genius’ young career.
             Xavier explanation and review of the street 
             woman dying in bed was mind-set shifting. WOW. 
Q-Trip: Pura Vida Cocktails is open at 6:30 and worth the 
             after visit steps from the Museum.

The Picasso museum in Barcelona is fascinating and very well displayed. We also went on a free Sunday so it was even better! The audio guide was fantastic and did cost 5 euro but well worth it. We spent about 3 to 4 hours and it was amazing as was Picasso!
This is a charming museum that includes some of Picasso's lesser known works of art, ceramics and sculpture. Lovely museum store, one of the best we visited in Spain.

How to get in is a bit confusing, went to the entrance to be told that we had to go out of the building, around the corner, obtain a ticket and then come back. We actually walked back in the direction from which we had come to do so. Not great signage.
The best part of this museum is the building itself, The exhibits, whilst interesting are nothing special which is disappointing after all it is a museum to showcase Picasso.
I was not entranced by the experience and even my wife was a trifle underwhelmed.
I am pleased that we went in as there were bits that were enjoyable and informative but on the whole I would not have missed much had we not gone. In fact there is no real collection and there did not seem to be any structure to the location and layout of the displays.
Staff were all very helpful and the place was not too crowded, but we were there in January.
Probably only worth a visit if you have a great interest in art.

Wednesday's you can get free entry at night but you Must know the date to book advance tickets! Highly recommend! I did not realize Picasso had such a wide variety of talents until this exhibit. It's fabulous.
Well, it was a disappointment. Very little to appreciate. Minimally, there should be onsite guide to host the visitors.

Museu Picasso is a must visit.   If you think you know Pablo Picasso’s (1881 - 1973) painting by his Blue or Rose periods, become enlightened by the masterpieces he produced as a teenager.  They are outstanding and classical—so very different than his later works when he went to Paris.  The museum is beautifully arranged, so the paintings have space to breathe; you can get surprisingly close to them.
Timed tickets are required.  Thursdays are free.  There is a senior price. The very worthwhile audio (5 euro) is very good and can be shared with another person.

The museum was lovely and my husband and I really enjoyed it. We did expect more because we are very big fans of Picasso and very familiar with his art. We saw much bigger and more serious exhibits of Picasso in New York. In this museum, called after his name, you will see only the early period. If you’d like to stay away from crowds, probably you should also come on a regular day and pay the admission. We booked our tickets on Sunday for Thursday because that’s the only way to book tickets for free admission on Thursday nights. We saw people being bounced at the door because you have to reserve timed tickets online and obviously they were sold out. Also, it was a bit problematic to find the entrance. Honestly, the first time in my life I got lost and couldn’t find a museum entrance (no proper signs, really). The gift shop has several sections and has many interesting things to offer. Art is spectacular but left us with a “that’s it?!” feeling. I guess we thought it would be much bigger and grand. We counted on at least two hours there, but at the end, we spent one hour only.
The museum has a wonderful collection of Picasso’s early academic work and illustrates his skill as traditional artist. The setting is also beautiful.

Picasso is undoubtedly one of the most acclaimed artists in the 20th century. Hence Pablo Picasso spent his formative teenage years in Barcelona, this Museu Picasso boasts the world's largest collection of his early art. This museum enabled me to trace the evolution of Picasso's works right back to when he was 10 years old, as he had already revealed his remarkable artistic genius. 
His earliest art was realistic and serious and no one would not be impressed with his skilful technique and psychological insight. When he was 15 years old, he entered art-school competitions with his breathtaking debut work "The First Communion". At art-school, he painted a number of powerful family portraits which had shown his techniques in painting expression and human anatomy. 
In his early 20s, he moved to Paris and his style had changed accordingly. His paintings showed he had followed the styles from a number of artists, such as Monet, Toulouse-Lautrec, Cezanne and Henri Matisse...etc. After the death of his best friend and his own poverty, it led Picasso to enter his Blue Period and as a result, he produced a series of "blue paintings" to match his mood. He started to paint not what he saw but what he felt. Later, Picasso came out from his blues and entered a period of innovative and prolific career by painting colourful and world-famous freed arts!
What I liked the most about this museum was it help me to discover his life through his paintings. Here below are some of his most famous collections at this museum:
1) Home amb boina (man in a beret): One of his paintings of the portraits of an old man in his village. (Pablo was only 13 years old when he painted this)
2) First Communion: Pablo's incredible debut work when he entered his art-school competitions at the age of 15 years old. (It's actually a portrait of his dad and his sister)
3) Pablo's self-portrait: You'd be amazed by how he saw himself when he painted his self-portrait!
4) L'Espera (Margot): Picasso's Margot was an evocative painting portraying a call girl whilst she was waiting for her customer.
5) Las Meninas Series: Based on the Velazquez painting Las Meninas, Picasso had created a series of Vas Meninas colourful paintings.
6) Science and Charity: He painted this when he was still a teenager. The doctor was Pablo's father, represents science. the nun represents charity and religion, as she was helplessly looking at the poor patient and showing death was inevitable.
7) Home Assegnt: One of Picasso's series of analytic cube paintings
8) The Blue painting series: Picasso's famous series paintings during his Blue Period.
9) The pigeon canvases: Picasso's paintings in his 80s.

We visited the museum on a Sunday late afternoon. There weren't many visitors there but maybe it was due to the poor weather on that day. We had a very good time there and would highly recommend it to anyone who wants to witness the early paintings from possibly the most famous painter in 20th century.
Tips:
Due to the lack of directions signs, the ticket office was very hard to find. We were queuing at 2 wrong places before we found the right queue. There were 3 entrances to the museum and the ticket office was the one in the middle.
There are lots of tourist visiting.  Buy your tickets days in advance and give yourself ample time to absorb the genius works, as you won’t be disappointed.

A stunning building in the heart of the city. Oodles of atmosphere in Born, an amazing location. It houses some of Picasso's very early work, where his genius is obvious even as a young boy. Wonderful. If you love art, this needs to be on your radar in Barcelona

This is a great museum to see in Barcelona . The museum has a complete series of Picasso's work from teenage to maturity. His works are marvelous and breathtaking. You can see his masterpieces in a chronological way. The workers were all really nice and helpful. You can get the free tickets for the first Sunday of every month.  Overall is a great place to visit and it can get very busy.
Definitely recommend a visit to this museum for adults (not families). With the audio guide you get to see how Picasso developed his unique style over the years.

This museum is a must see for art lovers to appreciate the journey Picasso took throughout his life and the influences of time and styles from his first painting and onward.  The building has been beautifully restored and the collection of artwork was donated largely by Picasso himself.
It was really cool thing to see, real works from him. Even though I'm not an artist, I really appreciate history. This is a fantastic museum to see.

My husband and I decided to visit this museum on a rainy afternoon. That morning, I bought our tickets and audio guide rentals (for the permanent collection) on my phone and chose a time that was not overly busy.  It’s helpful having occupancy information available on the museum’s website (available as you begin the purchase process). I received an immediate confirmation email with QR codes to use for entry. With our tickets on my phone, we were able to gain immediate entry on arrival and picked up our audio guides. No queues!

We highly recommend the audio guides which give detailed information for many of Picasso’s works. This museum is relatively small, and though it doesn't have Picasso's most famous works, it does a good job of focusing on his early years as an artist. It was clear that he was very talented at an early age. It was fascinating to explore Picasso’s beginnings and his development as an artist through his sketches, etchings, paintings, and ceramics. We particularly enjoyed Picasso’s series of interpretations of Velázquez’s "Las Meninas", especially after having seen the original at the Prado earlier in our trip.

Not only was the art worth looking at, so too were the buildings which housed the art. The museum occupies adjoining medieval stone palaces which feature lovely archways, staircases, and courtyards.

A quick walk from the Ramblas, this is a must see for anyone who enjoys Picasso.  Most of the works here are not as famous as those in other museums, however, they are still awe inspiring, from an incredible portrait painted when he was just 11 years old to works right before his death.  Strongly recommend that you buy tickets on line and buy a guided tour from the museum as well.

Although my husband and I aren’t art aficionados, we were very impressed with the Picasso museum.  The exhibits spanned from his childhood (what talent!!) through cubism. We did have a good which was helpful.

If you love art, do it. If you’re only doing it because you’re in Spain, either skip it and do it on the first Sunday of every month (I believe it’s free look it up on the site) or walk around the gothic quarter instead (basically where this museum is located). The museum itself is very small and in my opinion doesn’t hold very many important Picasso’s.
We really enjoyed this museum in the Gothic district of Barcelona.  It was easy to find.  I really liked the film they had on the reinactment of Picasso's Art.

Oh, it was fabulous. A biography of Picasso in an inspiringly atmospheric building, filled with works donated by family and friends. Sadly his most well-known works are in huge galleries in other countries. There were large gaps in the story.

Busted the Picasso museum in early October. It was just a block from our hotel in old town area. We happened to be there the first Sunday of the match both which was free admission. You had to make a timed reservation.  We chose 19:00, which gave us time to settle into the hotel and keep us busy as we waited for the late dinner hour in Barcelona. Entry was extremely easy with the timed tickets keeping the crowds down. The museum was easy to follow and had exits from as the years of Picasso art development, from young student to his retirement years in France. The place was very well organized and gave a great overview of his career with some of his most well known pieces on exhibit. I found a new interest in his work. Enjoyed it very much!

Is is me of the museum? I enjoyed this visit more than perevious visits. Perhaps I was more prepared as I had been reading about Picasso before our visit. I was quite taken by Picasso's early talent that he honed throughout his life. An amazing artist. Don't miss visiting when you are in Barcelona.

Getting started in the museum was a little confusing as there was little signage and when there were signs they didn't always seem accurate.

But once we had our tickets and backpacks all sorted and stowed away, the museum was thoroughly enjoyed. It was incredible seeing the timeline and progression of Picasso's work with very good explanations. This is a great museum to stop into and I'd highly recommend purchasing the ArTicket if you're interested in multiple art museums.
I highly recommend this museum in the Born area of Barcelona. It was fun walking the streets to get to the museum and the art was excellent. Highly recommend!
Follows his life through his paintings. Was the most gifted artist. Many of his works are there. You should not miss this. It is down a small alley way so you can walk past it. We did the first time.

Although Picasso was born in Andalucia and became famous in a Paris, Barcelona was his hometown.  This museum, off a narrow lane in the Gothic Quarter holds the art he sent home and in this way, represents the more personal art of his heart.  His progression from youthful experiments to first masterpiece - at age 14 - through his career unfolds in this old-school building with a small inner courtyard that brightens the hallways.  The gift shop has something at every price point.  Go outside and walk in the master’s footsteps!
OK, it's not THE world's greatest Picasso collection. But it is still great. Especially the :Las Meninas exhibit near the end (it's arranged chronologically.)

This museum covers some of the very early and very late Picasso works. We visited with our two teens, who are not huge art fans, and spent about an hour and a half exploring the museum. It focuses on his early and late years; the highlights for me were the various studies of Las Meninas and some of his blue period works. We also enjoyed the opportunity to see something different with his experiments into ceramics late in night. For someone who appreciates art casually, this was an enjoyable time. We pre-purchased our timed tickets in advance and were happy to be able to skip long lines and just walk in.

Alex was an excellent guide for the tour of the neighborhood and the Museum of Picasso. We started out with a pretty long walk around the area where Picasso lived when he was in Barcelona. The museum was certainly the highlight of the trip and then we discovered how well the walk and all of the details that Alex had shared enriched the experience in the museum.
Alex was also very friendly and on time and a thoughtful person to spend the afternoon with. We were very glad we decided to take the TripAdvisor tour of the Picasso museum.

My son loves Picasso’s work and I was introduced to it.Good audio commentary which brings the journey together . Price is very reasonable and we shared the Audio device and hence paid for just one person.The artists work has been displayed in a way that runs through his life, change in his art with description of how he changed some of other artists work to his own style .

Having only really seen Picasso's most famous works over the years, it was very cool to see his earlier work.  There were a number of painting that were traditional versus his more famous modern impressionist works.  Had a private guided tour from our fantastic tour company "Made for Spain".  Our guide had a ton of additional color to provide as we walked through the museu.

When we visited, this place was very crowded.  It was spring, the weather was warm, and the crowd made it even more so inside. I was stunned that the museum rooms were not air conditioned. If they pretend to be, it is not effective. I am surprised that the art doesn’t deteriorate, being so exposed to heat and humidity. The viewing experience is significantly affected by this feeling of wanting to escape to cool air. I’m also surprised that the museum makes no attempt to regulate the numbers of visitors who try to crowd into the rooms. A better system would greatly enhance each person’s ability to see the artists works, which are displayed in chronological order from room to room. I was really disappointed as a result, and was relieved to get through the place and get outside.

Starting from when he was a child (parents kept everything he did), this is a nice way to see how the painter’s style evolved over the years. However there appears to be a significant gap before his cubist period. Plan on taking at least an hour to peruse this fabulous collection. Many many examples of his paintings, sketches and even ceramics. Cheers!

I am a big fan of single artist museums and this one did not disappoint. I took the metro here which was pretty convenient. I used the audio tour which was a little old-fashioned, but had great information. I had a limited time to go through, but managed to get most of the tour done within about 1h 15min. It was great to see the whole range of Picasso's evolution and work.

Many early student works, this part is nowhere else to see and it was really intresting what was the start. Still we've expected to see all periods of Picasso's artistic carreer represented and the better story about it.  The Meninas were the highlight for us in this museum, at least funny. Other works seem to be more the leftovers, not the masterpieces. 
In total it was ok visit, considering we booked free tickets.

The queues are unbelievable! Therefore it's an absolute must to get tickets in advance online. Whilst I enjoyed the museum, the absence of any of his really well-known works made it slightly disappointing. It was very crowded inside too which made the experience a little cluttered. Still well worth doing though.

I visited the Picasso museum on a mission to convert my friend into becoming a fan of the artist.
The museum chronicles the artistic journey of Pablo from his beginnings as a classically trained painter (which to most people comes as a surprise) through to some of his greatest abstraction.  Of course it would be impossible to chart everything and his major cubist period is missed.
But the big hit - Picasso's homage to Velasquez's Las Meninas is shown in all its glory with some of the preparatory sketches as well.  This is the star of the show and if you have come from or are going to Madrid go and see Velasquez's original in the Prado.
This is a lovely museum operating with a timed entrance, but once inside it doesn't feel crowded and you are not herded around.
So, back to my friend...she admitted to now liking some of the early work - "Science and Charity" is here - but still believed that his abstraction could have been done by anybody. Sigh...
We are not huge art enthusiasts, but this was recommended to us and so glad we did! It was beautiful and interesting and loved the way it flowed.  Splendid!

We were happy to have such a passionate informed guide. We learned a lot about Picasso and history. It was well worth having the skip the line guided tour.
Even though one has a voucher or ticket, the museum is not very organized to know where the meeting place was. There were 10 different people looking around and  asking people but everyone gave different answers.
Alert...no back packs but they do have a locker room for a euro coin.

It's missing some of Picasso's greatest works obviously but still an amazing experience where you get to see the artist's different phases and learn about his life. A bit hard to find but overall a great visit and not overpriced like others.

While my wife was working at her convention, I went to the Picasso Museum (a little hard to find until after they open their doors; it’s on a tight little Barri Gotic alley).  Some cubism, but mostly remarkable for his earlier work.  It's amazing to see the talent he possessed as a teenager.

This museum gives you a glimpse into some of Picasso’s earlier work as well as some of his a few of his more famous pieces. In busy times, the ticket queue can be quite long, so I’d recommend booking a timed ticket online to skip the line. Not a huge museum, so you can take your time and get through everything in an hour or two.

Four of us were excited to visit this museum. After wandering around independently we all came to the same conclusion. It felt disjointed and hard to follow chronologically. We all left a bit disappointed. 

Only advice if you still want to go, book the first slot of the day, to avoid the crowds. We couldn’t believe the queues we saw waiting to get in on previous days.

Go early!!!!  Bring your earplugs if you are opting for the audio.  What more can I say it's the Picasso museum, the artwork is spectacular.  If your in a chair very accessible, but crowded.  Getting close enough to the art work to see the numbers to coordinate with your audio may be an issue.  Great gift shop

I really liked the Museum, a lot of early works by Picasso, not very convenient is the location of the halls in the Museum, the impression is created. that you walk in circles and haven't seen all the halls. But the paintings themselves are fascinating, especially a lot of early paintings by Picasso, which, the sea, nature, parks.

Interesting Museum, well Maintained in the old part of town.
Has Paintings and Photos from early childhood

What I loved most about this museum is a) the setting (there are some gorgeous rooms, and the part of Barcelona where it is situated, the older part, is a really lovely place to visit) and b) the earlier work.   There are so many pieces here that are not at all "typical" Picasso, and those were my absolute favorites!  It is so different from the Picasso Museum in Paris -- really special and also a quick visit -- takes less than an hour if you are pressed for time!  Be careful, though, as there are a lot of thieves in the area it seems, and our car was broken into, but luckily and miraculously, I didn't lose anything...

It’s a relatively small collection, but representative of his lifetime of work. There is great diversity of materials. It is worthwhile if you have enough time in Barcelona, but I would prioritize the major architectural sites before this.

I am not a Picasso fan but definitely appreciate art and I quite liked this gallery. The building is beautiful, has everything a gallery should have. Lockers for free and very nice gift shop with loads of interesting books as well. The exhibition is especially interesting as it has drawings and paintings from his early age too so if you aren't a fan of his more known works, you'll still find a few pieces you'll like. If you appreciate art, then this is a must do. I bought the ticket in advance but I haven't see a queue(October).

This museum is well worth a visit. We learned a lot about Picasso and how his art changed and varied over his lifetime. It was fairly crowded at times but not super packed. I recommend buying the headpiece to get insights into some of the paintings. Photos are allowed, no flash.

Definitely make sure to seek it out while walking the beautiful small cobblestone streets and alleys in El Born.  Tickets will sell out pretty quickly if there is rain in the forecast.

Currently, there is an exhibit of Picasso's photographic works in addition to the permanent collection of paintings.  There is no audio tour of the photographs.  Audio tour of paintings is about 90 minutes.  

Picasso was born in Spain, but lived most of his adult life in France, so this museum is smaller than the Picasso museum in Paris but covers much of his early works and provides a good overview of his prolific career.

On Thursdays after 6PM, you can enter for free IF you have a ticket (on phone/print) reservation.  You can do this as early as four days before.online.   Not a huge museum.  A quick stroll though it can be done in less than 1 hour.

We prebought tickets here for morning and it included headsets which worked great. So interesting to see the change of Picasso who started very young and continued to change and develop his art work as he aged. Housed in a beautiful old building, it was walking distance to our hotel, worth a visit.

Picasso fans will not be disappointed but be wary that it is difficult to follow the museum chronologically. 

Lovely gift shop. If you can book online in advance during the free entry times do so.

The museum does a wonderful job of walking you through Picasso's development as an artist.  The final exhibit ... showing Picasso's obsessive treatments of Velazquez' Las Meninas (one of my favorite paintings of all time) knocked my sox off.

Arrived in a school group with great anticipation. Enthusiasm dampened at the entrance by the staff and the rudeness of staff continued inside. Glad to leave the museum in the end, with disappointed young adults. A hostile place to visit particularly for people of colour.
